nodes.title: Article 2
nodes.summary: The partial document outlines that a "Unique Taxation" regime does not exempt gold and precious stone trading counters from their fiscal obligations. It specifies that these entities must still file declarations and pay various taxes and contributions, including property taxes, professional taxes on profits and salaries, import duties, and taxes specific to expatriate remuneration. It also states that individual miners and traders remain subject to taxes on professional income and turnover under a specific decree for small and medium enterprises.

nodes.title: Article 5
nodes.summary: This partial document is an annex to an interministerial decree from the Democratic Republic of Congo, dated May 4, 2001. It establishes a unified tax regime for the artisanal exploitation of precious and semi-precious stones. The main content is a detailed tariff table listing annual taxes, duties, and fees for the artisanal mining sector in US dollars. The table categorizes charges for different minerals (heterogenite, copper, cassiterite, coltan, diamond, gold) and breaks them down into: A) Mining title fees for diggers, traders, counters, and smelters; B) Remunerative taxes (percentage of export value) allocated to various state agencies; C) Administrative taxes for decentralized entities; and D) Export duties. The document concludes with signatures from the Ministers of Mines and Hydrocarbures and of Economy, Finances and Budget.
